1 introduction this chapter covers the stages of the selection process and how to shine at each the five skillsets of a data scientist how and when to demonstrate your skills in the job-hunting process using large language models (llms) such as chatgpt to improve interview results if you are looking for a data science job, this book will aid you in several ways.
first, it will help you improve your whole approach to job hunting.
part 1 of the book shows you how to craft a resume that will get you noticed, handle screening calls so you get an interview, and navigate all the other steps leading up to the job interview.
second, this book will help you prepare for the specific questions, drills, and assessments you'll encounter after you land the interview.
parts 2 and 3 provide sample questions—with extended answers—that you will likely get in any data science job interview.

in all three parts, this book will introduce ways to use large language models (llms) such as chatgpt to help you be more efficient and better prepared for every stage of the job-hunting process—from improving your resume to rehearsing your interview questions.

although both stages—job hunting and interview assessments—are essential to landing your dream job, candidates new to our industry will see the most immediate results by starting with part 1. if you are looking for your first job in data science, part 1 will show you tried-and-tested methods for securing interviews, even without prior experience.
the data science candidates i've worked with have found these strategies reassuring and effective.
most started landing interviews within a week of updating their process.
more experienced candidates with a few successful job hunts under their belts may prefer to start practicing the interview questions right away.
if you fall into this second category, feel free to skip ahead to part 2. if you have the time, though, i suggest reading part 1 to learn new strategies for landing
better positions with less competition and higher success rates.
in other words, you'll discover ways to spend less time on the job search and go on fewer interviews to get to the next step in your career.
this book will not provide general career advice or instruction in data science techniques or methodologies.
we leave the career advice and strategy to other books (such as emily robinson and jacqueline nolis's build a career in data science https://www.manning.com/books/build-a-career-in-data- science).
as for the data science basics, though we review key concepts and approaches while discussing the assessment questions and answers, this book will not teach technical concepts from scratch.
so, if you have not yet started learning data science or still need to be convinced that data science is a fascinating and rewarding field, you might not be able to make the most out of this book.
i suggest you take a course or bootcamp or study a good book on the fundamentals first.

leonard apeltsin's data science bootcamp: five real-world python projects https://www.manning.com/books/data-science- bookcamp could be a good text for covering the basics and building the foundational skills that you need in our profession.
i prefer self-paced courses with lots of practical exercises and well-organized bootcamps—especially if they come with a job guarantee and a recruiter to help you land your first job in the industry.
in this chapter, we start with a quick look at the steps to follow to land an interview; in fact, we'll look at three different approaches, each with its own set of steps.
the bulk of this chapter then explores the skill sets employers seek in data scientists.
we will pay special attention to how and when to demonstrate to the hiring team that you have these skills.
we will return to these skillsets throughout the book, so it's important that we use the same definitions and assumptions.
as in all the chapters, we'll also touch on approaches to using ai and other tools to improve your procedure and make it more efficient.
1.1 the selection process workflow
you can take many possible approaches to land an interview for your dream job.
i divide them into three basic categories.
the traditional and passive approaches (shown in figure 1.1) are linear and straightforward, and they start with submitting your resume for a specific advertised job.
in the traditional approach, you apply for jobs directly with the company or through a job website.
with the passive approach, you submit your resume to recruitment agencies, often through those same employment sites, and wait for agencies to call you.

figure 1.1 both the traditional and passive approaches to getting interviews can be divided into two stages: opportunity generation, and employer engagement, which is when a recruiting agency or the hr department at the company responds to your application.
to land an interview, you need to convince the employer that you will likely get the job.
you persuade them in three stages.
first, make your resume pop up when the recruiter runs a search.
second, craft a resume or application that convinces the recruiter in 5 seconds or less that you are a relevant candidate.
finally, convince the interviewer during your screening call that you will likely get the job if they send your resume to the hiring manager.
the traditional and passive approaches consist of linear sets of relatively low- effort steps.
if you don't get the first job, you try again for another job using
the same steps.
your resume or applications and screening call communication skills will improve as you iterate.
with the traditional approach, you can control which jobs you spend time on.
you can use the time saved to make your applications stand out.
alternatively, you can apply to many jobs per hour and trust that some will get past the filters.
jobs that are easy to apply to attract the most competitors, so you need to be ready to submit many applications.
the traditional approach works best for generalist data scientists open to working in any industry.
with the passive approach, you answer calls from recruiters about jobs you are not interested in.
still, you can use the screening call to give your recruiter more information about you to influence the employer to give you a chance for an interview.
most importantly, the recruiter will send only about three candidates to the employer, who is likely to look at them all.
so your chances of getting an interview and landing the job are much higher.
sometimes the employer will want their own screening call before starting the official selection process.
you will still save time because of all the jobs you are not applying for.

you can gain an additional advantage by following a deep and focused approach, which you can see in figure 1.2. figure 1.2 the deep and focused approach allows you to do without job portals, resume repositories, and recruiters.
the dotted arrows represent what you get when you don't obtain what that step aims to provide.
approaching the job search with a deep and focused strategy can yield great results, giving you a competitive advantage and helping you to discover the companies where you'd really like to work.
it does, however, require more effort.
instead of just browsing job sites, try researching companies that interest you to uncover job opportunities that may not be advertised.
if you can't find any suitable openings, try expanding your network in the direction of that employer.
networking can be incredibly helpful in learning more about a company, its selection process, and the most relevant people to talk
to.
you may even be able to secure an informational interview, which can help you stand out from other candidates.
remember, not all types of preferential access lead to the same point in the selection process, so it's important to be aware of the potential outcomes.
ultimately, the more familiar you are with the organization and its people, the better your chances of success.
all three approaches can be effective, depending on your needs and desires, the job market, and your timeframe.

1.2 data science skills and job-hunting steps the raison d'être of this section is twofold: to identify the essential skills a data scientist needs to have, so you can self-assess your mastery and then focus on those where you need to improve.
to signpost where and when in the selection process to demonstrate each skill.
1.2.1 the five skillsets to paraphrase liam neeson in taken: data scientists have a very particular set of skills, skills acquired over a very long career.
skills that make you a unicorn for your future employer.
although he was referring to himself as an ex-cia officer rather than a data scientist, it also rings true for our profession.
i would go even further and say that we don't have just one set of skills that makes us unique.
we have five.
and they don't tend to occur in the same person by random chance.
in figure 1.3, you can see a famous venn diagram describing four skill sets.
i would add a fifth: scientist skills, such as curiosity, critical thinking, and creativity.
figure 1.3 our starting point for discussing data science skills.
these four skillsets are not always enough to succeed in our profession.
that's why i've added "scientist skills" to the mix.
in short, data scientists need to be:1) organizational problem solvers, 2) scientists, 3) statisticians, 4) data programmers, and 5) communicators.
so we could define data scientists as professionals who solve problems with a scientific approach, usually in organizations using data, statistics, and machine learning.
we will take a close look at these five skillsets in this chapter.
but first, i want to show you how they tie in to the job-search process.
1.2.2 the job-hunting steps figure 1.4 lists the five skillsets, along with the skills that go into each set, and where and when you will have a chance to demonstrate each of them in the job hunt.
the steps or activities displayed in the table commence before the job hunt starts.
we need a resume, a cover letter, and a project portfolio, although only the first one is mandatory.
you can find these steps at the top of the table.
then we search for a suitable job and eventually have a screening call where the recruiter will determine whether we will undergo a deeper assessment or be discarded.
finally, the assessment stage breaks down into behavioral interviews, technical quizzes, case interviews, and take-home exercises.
all these steps combined are what we refer to as the "job-hunting process".
figure 1.4 double entry matrix showing at what points in the selection process you can demonstrate each skill (green).
the fact that you have multiple opportunities to show them doesn't mean you can stop showing a skill at any point.
employers look for consistency.
the skills listed in figure 1.4 will help you get the best results when looking and interviewing for a job.
you can use these skills strategically to demonstrate that you have them during your assessments.
yellow in the figure marks instances where a skill improves your job-hunt efficiency, while green marks opportunities to prove the skill directly to your future employer.
notice how not all steps of the job-hunting process benefit from both
approaches, and not all skills have an impact through both avenues.
for example, you could use data programming skills to build a job opportunity scrapper.
still, it will not be worth your time unless you want to put together a project for your portfolio (and i'm sure you can come up with better project ideas).

in contrast, while no step of the selection process directly assesses your networking skills, your performance will be better if you've gathered intelligence through your network about how to obtain the best results.
if you are hitting a brick wall and not obtaining the desired results, looking into this inventory of skills will help you diagnose where to focus to get the outcomes you are after.
now let's go over each set of skills one by one.
as we do so, i'll signpost the chapters where we will treat these tactics in more depth.
1.2.3 problem solver skills being an organizational problem solver is the most crucial characteristic of a data scientist.
it is not a defining one, as many other professions focus on solving problems, but it's the one that makes you valuable to your employer.
understanding the business you will work in, prioritizing projects, and systematically generating solutions are skills that make you a good problem solver.
product sense interviews, a type of case interview, are ideal for the employer to gauge how quickly you will start generating value for the company.
however, because they often rely on candidates' familiarity with the employer's key metrics, it isn't an objective measurement of your general capability to solve problems.
so invest heavily in researching the company and the product!

from showing impact figures in your resume to clearly framing your problem and solution strategy in the take-home exercise and your project portfolio to using the bottom line as a guiding principle of your decisions when discussing a project, you can influence the perception the employer has of you in the problem-solving dimension by making it part of your communication style.
1.2.4 scientific skills this set of skills is more specific to data scientists and adjacent roles than the previous one.
data analysts, data scientists (including product dss), and machine learning engineers need this skillset.
you need a scientific spirit that breaks into the three cs: curiosity, critical thinking, and creativity.
these will be assessed at a different level depending on the stage of the selection process you are in.
case interviews evaluate your thinking process to see if you can apply a systematic approach to hypothesis generation and information gathering to solve problems.
product sense interviews are the most notorious type of case interview.
not all data scientists will have a case interview, but almost everyone will face a take-home exercise.

to complete these exercises successfully, you need the curiosity and creativity to identify solution opportunities and critical thinking to interpret your results in a way that you can confidently drop the approaches that won't work.
finally, some behavior interviews and screening calls may ask you to explain how you solved hard problems in the past or provide simple hypothetical problems for you to propose a solution to.
1.2.5 statistics and machine learning skills this skillset is the 'dark magic' that makes data science sexy.

it still scares people and is, together with data programming, one of the main barriers to entry into our industry, not because of their difficulty necessarily, but because many people dislike these two fields and find them more inaccessible than they really are.
these skills go beyond fitting models.
it is even more important to have clear criteria for selecting the right algorithm, understand the assumptions on which they are based and be capable of interpreting the results.
the most common way to evaluate these skills is during a good behavioral interview in which you can explain your thinking process and discuss your
approach.
this conversation may happen at any time, from the screening call to the q&a segment of your presentation at the end of your take-home exercise.
assessors will also look for assumption breaches and irrational choices in your take-home exercise and portfolio.
some tech companies will also have statistics and machine learning conceptual challenges to test how comfortable you feel with the core concepts.
probably the most common one is asking: "what's a p-value?"

1.2.6 data programming skills under data programming, we find the skills of using programming languages (such as sql, r, and python) to work with data, including obtaining, exploring, cleaning, and transforming.
feature engineering (creating and selecting variables), statistical modeling, and machine learning are additional, value-adding ways to use programming skills with data.
assessors will evaluate your data programming skills mainly by looking at your take-home exercise and portfolio.
for example, if you program in python, they will be looking for a breadth of methods, the ability to create from scratch functions and classes, and how well your code suits the problem.
companies that want to verify you can "think with code" also have technical assessments focused on one programming language.
they look for the same evidence as in the previous paragraph, but you can ask clarifying questions and have a time constraint.

additionally, during your screening call and behavioral interviews, you may get questions about, for example, your data cleaning process or examples of tough data cleaning situations you've experienced.
1.2.7 communication skills we have already covered in the previous subsections the importance of communication to maximize your influence and impact at work.
the value you generate with your communication skills is evidence of the value you can
deliver to your next employer.
this proof reduces the risk they perceive in hiring you, transforming you into a more interesting proposition.
we can break down communication skills into five categories: translating data science, collaboration, reporting, and presenting to leadership.
the employer evaluates these skills primarily through the behavioral interview and the screening call.
they ask you to explain a concept in non- technical terms, such as confidence intervals, and talk about projects in which you worked with colleagues with different skillsets.
but also, you can show you are easy to work with by making your take-home exercise and project portfolio easy to understand and replicate.
the presentation at the end of your take-home exercise is a great opportunity to leave the hiring manager with a last positive impression before they make a decision.
after reviewing all these skills, how do you think you stack up?
what areas does your future employer care the most about?
which skills do you still need to develop?
mark the relevant boxes in figure 1.2 as a self-assessment.
evaluating yourself without an objective assessment could be difficult, but the remaining chapters will give you more structure and granularity to accomplish this goal.

1.3 the ai-enhanced data science job-hunting machine now that we know what employers will be looking for and the steps you will go through in the selection process let's look at how we can use technology to make it all more effective and efficient by using large language models (llms) such as chatgpt.
these models are usually language transformers, a type of neural network more efficient at working with text so that it can go beyond a word-by-word analysis.

when the neural network architecture is large enough (billions of parameters) and is trained on large amounts of text, the model benefits from emerging capabilities such as following instructions or symbolic understanding.
when these models are generative and are paired with a good user interface, they can help humans solve problems faster.
the
more reliably llms solve problems, the more productive users become.
this enhanced efficiency, in turn, makes the economic impact more significant.
this reliability depends on two factors: the quality of the model and how well you communicate with it.

since the models are already improving exponentially, the rest of the book will focus on the latter, writing better messages (prompts) for the models to help you with your job-hunting efforts in a way that you obtain consistent results.
toward the end of each chapter, you will find a section to help you use prompt engineering to speed up what the chapter instructed you to do.
sometimes, llms can give you something better than what you have time to create on your own.
while writing this book, there have been so many changes in llms and ai that i had to update those sections constantly.
i can't do this after publishing, so i started a site where i keep my prompt engineering guides up-to-date.
it also has my ai analyses and news for you to stay current.
sign up for the newsletter at ai.fosshub.com to get the latest.
don't worry.
i won't spam you.
although the llm handicaps highlighted in this section will fade away, critical thinking and inquisitiveness will still be valuable safety traits for you and your employer.
not all valuable tools are ai-based, though.
you will also learn about other tools that will improve your job search.
1.3.1 llms privacy concerns when using chatgpt, be aware that openai currently collects what you type in the chat interface to improve the gpt models.
once the algorithm is trained on this data, removing it from the model is impossible, and other chatgpt users may gain access to that information as part of the output received from their queries.
avoid entering sensitive information, such as your customers' personal identifiable information or trade secrets.
this is critical to your organization's reputation and operation and a competitive advantage no matter where you are based.
if you live in the eu, it is even more critical as you may be complicit in breaching the region's data privacy legislation.
you can opt out of data collection by disabling the chat history or
deleting the conversations you consider to be sensitive from your history.
you can also avoid data collection by using their api through your ide or openai's playground, which doesn't record your inputs, allowing you to avoid this issue.
the same concerns apply to google's bard.

you can turn it off, but it won't delete your previous activity unless you do it manually, which you can do at https://myactivity.google.com/product/bard anthropic's claude 2's privacy settings default to not use your prompts for training the core model.
however, if your prompts are flagged as breaching their trust and safety guidelines, they will use your activity to train the model that prevents the breaches.
1.3.2 llms knowledge limitations llms knowledge coverage is uneven.
you'll see surprisingly insightful outputs on one topic followed by useless, or worse, misleading information on a different one.
this experience has made many overly trust llms while others gave up on them due to the lack of consistency.
you can do better.
treat llms as assistants who do their best to help you, even when they don't know the answers to your questions.
these assistants are so keen they can even hallucinate a solution to feel they are doing their job.
you can't trust them to be factual.
get inspiration and a starting point for work from them, and then apply your human judgment to adapt, validate and adapt to your situation.
the foundational llms that we have access to are not very good at math.
this handicap is not as limiting as it sounds, as there are plugins for chatgpt, such as walframalpha or code interpreter, that solve the problem.
you just need to pay for chatgptplus.
otherwise, keep calculations to yourself.
1.3.3 ai misuse we will cover many legitimate uses throughout the book.
however, there are
cases in which the use of ai can have a direct negative impact on the other party.
for example, openly using github copilot to help you code faster benefits your employer and you.

however, using gptengineer to mindlessly create your portfolio that you can't understand, much less defend in front of your interviewer, gives you a short-lived benefit that makes the employer's hiring cycle longer.
even if you don't look at this from an ethical perspective, you can see how the hiring manager may introduce additional filters in the selection process to avoid this situation.
when the practice becomes extended enough, you will find yourself going through longer selection processes and paying the price.
we will stick just to the principles of beneficence, nonmaleficence, transparency, and factuality for most of the applications of ai that we will be discussing in the book.
this is the bare minimum you should consider when using these tools, but i encourage you to learn and incorporate more aspects of data ethics in your professional workflow.

1.4 summary approach the selection process for a data science job using traditional, passive, or deep and focused strategies depending on the difficulty of the job you are aiming for and the career capital you've built.

develop the five essential skillsets for success in the job hunt: problem- solving skills, scientific skills, statistics and machine learning skills, data programming skills, and communication skills.
demonstrate these skillsets at different stages of the job-hunting process, including resumes, screening calls, behavioral interviews, technical quizzes, case interviews, and take-home exercises.
improve efficiency and effectiveness in job-hunting by utilizing large language models (llms), such as chatgpt, for tasks like resume crafting and interview preparation.
be aware of the caveats that come with working with llms.
for instance, privacy concerns mean you may want to avoid the input of sensitive information and investigate options to conversations or opt out of data collection or delete conversations.
also recognize the limitations of llms in terms of knowledge coverage and maths.
overcome them with walframalpha, code interpreter, and
external integrations utilize ai tools responsibly, adhering to beneficence, nonmaleficence, transparency, and factuality principles.
continually assess and identify areas for skill improvement throughout the job-hunting process.

2 crafting your resume and narrative this chapter covers how recruiters parse resumes optimizing your resume to get interviews reframing your non-tech roles into relevant experience inducing fear of missing out (fomo) in recruiters and employers speeding up the process using ai even if you are happy with your current resume, this chapter will show you how recruiters and hiring managers view your resume and how to ensure they don't ignore it.
you wouldn't believe how many candidates i've met who described themselves as 'happy with their resume' but were leaving the most critical information off it.
within a week of reworking their resume, they started getting more interviews than they could take.
no matter how experienced you are in data science, this chapter will help you get more interviews and qualify for more senior roles.
we'll see how to craft a resume that makes recruiters and hiring managers want to call you to begin the selection process.
whether you use a traditional, passive, or deep-and-focused approach, you’ll need to craft a resume, test its effectiveness, and improve it accordingly.
in figure 2.1, you can see the iterative process to follow to improve your resume.

figure 2.1 after collecting enough samples of job descriptions similar to the job we want, we will extract the language patterns and use them to craft a resume that works well with machines and humans.
then we will share it with recruiters to see if they find it deserving of a screening call.
we'll keep alternating these last two steps until the resume generates enough attention from recruiters.
we will start by understanding the role of a resume in the selection process.
then we will spend most of the chapter exploring the four factors (visibility, relevance, searchability, and fomo) that will get you recruitment calls just from your resume.
this chapter will go from the basics to advanced persuasion tactics to make your resume irresistible.
bonus track: you will learn how to identify experiences you thought were irrelevant (but were not) and make them count in your resume.
this change alone could boost your career by allowing you to bypass a junior position and qualify sooner for more senior roles.
but first, let's look at the role of your resume in the selection process.
hint: think of your resume as marketing collateral.
2.1 resume as marketing collateral when running a marketing campaign, you'd use multiple types of assets.

for example, copy (text of all lengths and styles) and pictures to create ads, a website to convince the prospective customer that this is the right product for them, and other resources that will be in direct contact with your target audience.
we generally call these materials marketing collateral.

i like to think of resumes (or cvs as they are known in some places outside the us) as marketing collateral because they both contain information and powerful messaging to drive the behavior we want in our counterparty without us needing to be present.
your resume is most critical in the time leading to your screening call.
the main goal for marketing materials and resumes is to increase the number of opportunities at the beginning of the process.
even though prospective customers or, in our case, interviewers and recruiters will continue to check your cv during the rest of the selection process, it is still most important in
attracting initial interest.
because you are at the beginning of the sales or selection process, you are still fighting for the attention of your target audience.
don't expect conscientious deliberation of pros and cons at this stage.
instead, within seconds your audience will decide whether to continue reading or skip to the next piece of content or resume, in our case.
because of these quick decisions at the beginning of the hiring process, clarity, readability, and visibility are crucial in a resume.
we will explore this in-depth in the next section.
to summarize for now: good cvs get you callbacks from recruiters and open the doors to conversations with hiring managers.
you can't even start the sales or selection without good marketing collateral unless you have a strong network.
2.2 visibility here, by visibility, i'm referring to how easy it is to find the critical information that recruiters and hiring managers are looking for.
this variable is the first of the four key resume factors discussed in this chapter.
recruiters will look at your resume only for a few seconds before deciding whether to contact you or move on to the next resume.
that means nobody will read the resume in full the first time they see it.
in those few seconds, whatever is important needs to be easy to spot by someone who is just scanning the document.
you may have heard advice regarding a resume's maximum length.
the size of your resume will not be a problem if you clearly show that you are an excellent match for the role from the beginning of the document.
length becomes problematic when the critical information that recruiters seek is hidden, located at the end, or is otherwise difficult to find.
in practice, this is how it works.
the recruiter looks for evidence in your cv to confirm that you are a good match.
they want you to be a good match, but until they find the right words, they will operate on the assumption that you are not.
if it helps, you can think of null hypothesis significance testing
(nhst): wanting to reject the null hypothesis but only doing so if we have evidence for it after concluding the experiment.
in other words, the recruiters' null hypothesis is "the candidate is not a good match".
to reject it, they will have a look at the first of your resume.
if that's not conclusive, they may "run another experiment"[1] (check the next ), but they may also cut their (time) loss and move on to the next candidate.
because not everyone will turn the , your chances of receiving a call back just dropped.
recruiters find your latest experience the most insightful.
the more pages your resume has, the more diluted the evidence is.
all else being equal, you would need to check more pages to get enough evidence to consider you a good match.
each time recruiters need to decide whether or not to turn the , the probability increases that they simply won't turn it.
instead, they'll stop reading and put it in the "no" pile.
the takeaway: shorter resumes with all the critical information clearly displayed on the first will quickly and efficiently give recruiters what they need.
if you are a good fit, your resume won't be rejected unjustifiably at the beginning of the selection process.

getting past this first obstacle is crucial because it opens the door to many more opportunities—even if you do not get hired for the position, the recruiter will save your details for other jobs that might be a better fit.
2.2.1 resume structure in data science, the most critical information is your experience.
so don't hide it!
after your name and contact information, the first section should be your experience.
even when your relevant experience is relatively limited, your resume should start with it, leaving the education section and all other sections for later.
why are recruiters so interested in what you have done before?
because, at some level, they understand what psychological scientists have come to agree on: "past behavior is a great predictor of future behavior".
in our case, the
fact that you were able to solve problems using data science in the past is a good predictor that you will be able to do it again.
we can extend this to the results that you were able to deliver in previous jobs.
if you had a substantial positive impact on your employer, it is more likely that your new employer won't have to fire you for incompetence.
although in the case of results, we need to consider many more work environment variables that make the prediction less reliable.
long resumes may be susceptible to hiding the key information on a second (or third) , but one- resumes can also succumb to this mistake by not placing work experience at the top.
see figure 2.2 for an example.

your work history includes specific skills, projects, budgets, and other details that can demonstrate your appropriateness to the position—all key information demonstrating your relevance at a glance.
so, if your work experience is not at the top of your resume, you will likely reduce the key information you present on the first .

as with visibility— indeed all four of the resume factors from this chapter-- the harder it is to spot the key info, the less likely the recruiter will call you for a screening interview; this, in turn, reduces your opportunities right at the very beginning of the selection process.
figure 2.2 structure of the top of your resume.
name at the top immediately followed by your contact information (this is your implicit call to action).
add a personal statement if that's customary in the country you are applying to; otherwise, start listing your job experience following the title – company – period worked headers.

if, in the country in which you want to work, it is customary to start a resume with a personal statement, keep it short, with smaller type, and with formatting distinct enough that recruiters can skip it easily.
because that's what they want to do and what you want them to do.

you want to post your cv on sites where employers and recruiters will run the most searches for data science candidates.

tick it.

recruiters prefer candidates who are 'actively looking' for a new job.

then update on sunday night or monday morning.

this seasonal pattern means they will tend to run a new search on a job site then.
you want to show up on that search as an actively looking candidate, and you do that by updating your cv.
in addition, remember to keep your linkedin profile in sync with your cv if you do any major overhaul.

they often compare it with your resume.
if they are not aligned, it may confuse them and trigger unnecessary questions, or even worse, make you fall into the 'too difficult' category and not give you a call.
if you can't keep your linkedin profile synced, make it private to avoid recruiters and hiring managers seeing incongruencies.

3 the project portfolio and the take- home exercise this chapter covers how and when to invest time in your project portfolio solving take-home exercises in the most effective way when and how to skip project portfolios and take-home exercises the best way to predict the future performance of job candidates is to observe their past performance.
the second-best way is to simulate a work situation and see how the candidates perform.

because the first option is not feasible (unless you are applying for a job in the same company you've worked at for a while), most of the selection processes you will encounter will resort to the second approach.
there are two ways to simulate an actual work situation.
the company leads one: the take-home exercise.
the candidate leads the other: the project portfolio.
a data science project portfolio is a collection of your best work as a data scientist.
it includes code, visualizations, and your own commentary.
for example, it could consist of problems you solved in your bootcamp, projects you assigned yourself, or actual work applications (as long as your former employers don't mind you sharing these).
in a take-home exercise, the hiring committee gives you a dataset, a problem to solve, and sometimes a series of questions.
they usually ask you to solve the problem and prepare a presentation for the interview panel that discusses your approach and solution.
let's look at both in detail, focusing on how to use them to your advantage.
3.1 the data science project portfolio
sometimes, a project portfolio can be extremely useful.
still, it won't move the needle in most cases because most employers rely on your resume and technical assessments to screen and decide who to hire.
a project portfolio can help you get interviews if you don't have previous data science experience.
employers may request them when hiring for junior roles.
if you can provide an impressive catalog of data projects you've written and examples of their output, recruiters and hiring managers may overlook your lack of on-the-job experience.
the portfolio also gives you something to talk about during your interviews.
but it is when graduating from a data science bootcamp that your portfolio will be the most useful, as the boot camp's recruiters will be using it to find you a job.
in the opposite scenarios, for example, when you have ten years of very intense work that didn't leave you much time to make your portfolio look nice, you have two options.
either improve your portfolio or don't promote it at all.
a bad portfolio can hinder your chances of getting an interview.
you should pay as much, if not more, attention to detail to your portfolio as to your resume.
i don't see many resumes plagued with spelling and grammar errors, yet these are common in the project portfolios i have reviewed.
there is a crucial caveat with project portfolios: they take more time, effort, and skill from the recruiter.
(you already know how much time, effort, and skill they take on your part!).
it is much easier and faster to decide if you are a good candidate by looking at your resume than by parsing through your code, the cells output, and visualizations.
this additional ease is especially true for generalist recruiters who haven't specialized in data science jobs.
because of this extra effort, project portfolios rarely improve your chances of getting an interview with a company.
at the early stages of the hiring process, most likely, no one will look at it.
the project portfolio generally gives you an edge only when the selection process guarantees that the employer will see it.

there are three main situations in which you can trust that someone will look at your portfolio: with internships at large corporations or public entities, when working with a bootcamp internal recruiter, and when you already have captivated the person that will be reviewing your portfolio to such extent that you have their full
attention and interest.
let's go through these three scenarios one by one.
large corporations and public entities with large budgets can afford to assemble a committee to review portfolios.
generally, these committees review the portfolio of applicants applying for internships and some entry- level jobs.
candidates for these positions may have little to no work experience, so the portfolio plays a crucial role in demonstrating their skills and abilities.
more of these employers are expecting candidates to have a portfolio nowadays.
data science bootcamps often hire recruiters to work as part of the organization to find jobs for their graduates faster.
that way, they can advertise high success rates and start collecting student payments sooner (as many don't start charging until the student finds a job).
the recruiter looks at the portfolio you produced from the bootcamp and then, in turn, uses it as a sales tool when reaching out to employers.
let's say that during the course, you built a project relevant to a specific employer.
if the recruiter has looked at your portfolio, they can point out the relevance to the employer, who can see how you could add value to their company.
if you remember, this is the strongest of the four types of fomo.
so, creating a portfolio makes a positive difference in such situations.
finally, a deep and focused approach allows you to build a relationship with key people at your target employer that increases their willingness to have a look at your project portfolio.
notice how special these situations are.
for most job hunts, it may not be worth the effort to create a portfolio, at least at the beginning stages when you are simply trying to get noticed so you can get a callback from a recruiter.
if you are not getting the number of interviews you would like, put your time and effort into improving your resume.
if everything else fails, put yourself in one of those three situations.
if you have the time or need practice, there's nothing wrong with creating a portfolio.
if nothing else, building your portfolio will be great practice for completing your take-home exercise.
for those who do decide to do one, let's see what goes into a data science project portfolio.
most people share their project portfolio through a github link because github allows you to show your code and, in specific locations, the rendered results.
those two outputs will help showcase your ability to communicate with non-technical stakeholders.
and in part, we use github because we inherit this tradition from software developers.
it also doesn't hurt that it is free!
3.1.1 selecting a topic, dataset, and skills to showcase first, you need to choose the right type of project to prove to the recruiter and prospective employer that you are competent.
even more than competent, let's make them feel they will miss out if they don't contact you.
let's see how the project's topic, dataset, and complexity help us get this reaction.
if you already know what sector you want to work in, choose a subject as closely related as possible to the employer or industry you are targeting and show them the impact you can deliver.
for example, let's say you want to work for an online takeaway delivery company.
you have two relatively relevant projects: one that analyzes city bike ridership data and the other that builds a recommendation algorithm.
yes, both could be useful to your prospective employer, but combining those projects with food data would be much more eye-catching.
now, you are showing value to that specific company and maximizing fomo!
if you are open to multiple sectors, focus on solving a problem that could make most companies money.
for example, could you build a model to identify which customers are most likely to purchase so that a salesforce could reach out to them sorted by their likelihood to buy?
or one that estimates the selling value of a property so that you can identify good deals on the buy and sell side?
these kinds of projects would clearly affect the bottom line of a wide range of companies.
pick an original dataset, or even better, collect your own data.
a project will be valued more if you gather and manipulate your own data and less if you use a kaggle dataset or "one of those datasets that everyone in bootcamps plays with".
i'm looking at you titanic, boston housing, pima diabetes, and mnist datasets.
my rule of thumb is that if you can find
tutorials online about it, your project will not likely look original.

and given that all bootcamp students are encouraged to keep blogs and publish on medium.com or towardsdatascience.com and social media now, chances are that if a dataset is moderately easy to access, plenty of people have already published on it.

4.1 applying directly to job openings

4.4.1 the cover letter cover letters are meant to enhance resumes.

structure of an effective cover letter interest in the job: highlight your reasons for wanting to work at the specific company.
mention unique sources of information about the company to showcase genuine interest.
self-introduction: use summaries from your cv and fomo (fear of missing out) statements to present yourself as an indispensable candidate.
include relevant links that support your claims.
